coredata.dc:title: Rational design of Schottky heterojunction with modulating surface electron density for high-performance overall water splitting
coredata.dc:creator: Deng, Lequan
Zhang, Kang
Shi, Dong
Liu, Shengfu
Xu, Deqin
Shao, Yongliang
Shen, Jianxing
Wu, Yongzhong
Hao, Xiaopeng
coredata.dc:description: The development of non-precious metal electrocatalysts to synergistically expose more active sites and optimize intrinsic activity still remains a huge challenge. Transition metal layered double hydroxide (LDH) has a great potential in electrocatalysis due to its unique sheet-like nanostructure and low cost. However, the poor electrical conductivity and sluggish water dissociation process hinder their development. Herein, the interface effect of Schottky heterostructure between cobalt-iron hydroxide and MXene and surface electron density modification with phosphorus (P) doping provide an efficient method to solve these crucial issues. The novel Schottky heterostructure catalyst (P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF) with self-driven charge transfer can enhance electron transport efficiency. In addition, the surface electron density optimized by P-doping will promote the ability of H+/OH- ion adsorption and redox reaction for overall water splitting. The as-prepared P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF requires overpotentials of only 85 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER and 252 mV at 200 mA cm−2 for OER in 1.0 M KOH, respectively. And under an alkaline electrolyzer, it can be driven 10 mA cm−2 at a low voltage of 1.52 V for overall water splitting with remarkable durability for 100 h. More broadly, this design concept is universal and it can be extended to design other transition metal-based catalysts.

Schottky heterojunction
bimetallic hydroxide
density function theory calculations
water splitting

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: a) Schematic illustration of the fabrication procedure of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF with a cross-section view of the heterostructure; b) SEM image of single-layer MXene. SEM images of before c) (CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF) and after phosphating treatment d) (P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF); e) TEM image and f) HRTEM image of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF; g) Elemental mappings of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF (inset of (f): Lattice fringes and corresponding angle).

a) XRD patterns P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, and CoFe-LDH/NF; b) EPR spectra and c) O 1s XPS spectra of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF and CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF; d) Fe 2p and e) Co 2p XPS spectra of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, and CoFe-LDH/NF; f) P 2p XPS spectra of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF.

a) LSV curves, b) Overpotentials at 10 mA cm−2 and 100 mA cm−2, c) Tafel slopes, d) EIS curves, and e) Current density (△J=(Ja-Jc) vs different scan rates and the corresponding linear slopes for P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, CoFe-LDH/NF, MXene/NF, and NF; f) Current density–time curves of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF during HER process.

a) LSV curves, b) overpotentials at 200 mA cm−2, c) Tafel slopes, and d) EIS curves of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, CoFe-LDH/NF, MXene/NF, and NF, e) Current density–time curve of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF during OER processes; f) XPS spectra of O 1s for P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF after OER cycle test.

a) The LSV curves of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF(+)//P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF(−) and IrO2 @NF(+)//Pt/C@NF(−) toward overall water splitting; b) Chronoamperometry measurement of the overall water splitting at 10 mA cm−2 and 100 mA cm−2; c) DOS of the MXene, CoFe-LDH, and CoFe-LDH@MXene heterostructure; d) DOS of the CoFe-LDH@MXene and P-CoFe-LDH@MXene; e) The atomic structure diagram (upper) and charge difference distribution (bottom) of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene; f) Energy band diagram of metallic MXene and CoFe-LDH after Schottky contact.

head.ce:title: Rational design of Schottky heterojunction with modulating surface electron density for high-performance overall water splitting

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: State Key Laboratory of Crystal Materials, Shandong University

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The development of non-precious metal electrocatalysts to synergistically expose more active sites and optimize intrinsic activity still remains a huge challenge. Transition metal layered double hydroxide (LDH) has a great potential in electrocatalysis due to its unique sheet-like nanostructure and low cost. However, the poor electrical conductivity and sluggish water dissociation process hinder their development. Herein, the interface effect of Schottky heterostructure between cobalt-iron hydroxide and MXene and surface electron density modification with phosphorus (P) doping provide an efficient method to solve these crucial issues. The novel Schottky heterostructure catalyst (P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF) with self-driven charge transfer can enhance electron transport efficiency. In addition, the surface electron density optimized by P-doping will promote the ability of H+/OH- ion adsorption and redox reaction for overall water splitting. The as-prepared P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF requires overpotentials of only 85 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER and 252 mV at 200 mA cm−2 for OER in 1.0 M KOH, respectively. And under an alkaline electrolyzer, it can be driven 10 mA cm−2 at a low voltage of 1.52 V for overall water splitting with remarkable durability for 100 h. More broadly, this design concept is universal and it can be extended to design other transition metal-based catalysts.

ce:section.ce:para: The electrochemical water splitting is a promising method to alleviate environmental and energy issues [1]. However, the practical application of hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions and the high overpotentials are severely limited by the sluggish kinetics [2,3]. At present, the current state-of-the-art electrocatalysts mainly involve noble Pt metal and Ir/Ru-based oxides [4,5]. Unfortunately, the widespread application of these precious catalysts are hindered by their natural rarity and high cost [6]. To this end, effective strategies are still in place required to realize cost-effective electrocatalysts with Pt-like activity suitable for electrocatalytic water splitting [7,8].

Up to date, researchers emphasized transition metal-based compounds hold great promise as the alternatives of noble metal catalysts [9–11]. Due to the synergistic interface effect of favorable kinetics, bulk redox activity with large basal spacing, and multiple metal centers [12–15], two-dimensional (2D) ultrathin layered double hydroxides (LDH) containing charge compensating anions (e.g., NO3-, CO3 2-, etc.) and positively charged metal hydroxide layers are the most promising nonprecious electrocatalysts in alkaline electrolyte solutions [15–18]. In particular, recent studies have shown that due to the strong synergy between Co and Fe ions and greater electronegativity of them, CoFe-based LDHs are expected to be used as water splitting electrocatalysts [19]. Notwithstanding, their performance is still far from satisfactory by its low electrical conductivity, limited electrochemical active surface area (ECSA), and sluggish water dissociation process [19,20]. The above problems are usually solved by introducing conductive substrates (mostly soft carbon materials) to support or grow LDHs, forming LDHs/CNT, LDHs/reduced graphene oxides, LDHs/carbon paper, and other composites [11,19]. To enhance the linking to LDHs, the carbon matrix could be modified by functional groups (such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, epoxy, or alkoxy). However, the electronic conductivity will be diminished by the increasing sp3 bonds. Moreover, due to the electrostatic interaction between sheets and strong π-π stacking interactions, the above composites are easy to crumple into balls [21,22].

Inspired by the physics of semiconductors, to simultaneously solve these problems, a smart strategy is developed by designing Schottky heterostructure interfaces, in which the heterointerface can drive the electron flow across the heterointerface spontaneously, resulting in a relatively stable interface and enhanced metallicity [22,23]. 2D transition metal carbonitrides/carbides (e.g., Ti3C2, Nb2C, V2C, and Ti3CN, etc.), MXenes, with the hydrophilic surface, ultrahigh conductivity, and high chemical and mechanical stability have attracted rapidly raising interests in vast fields [24–26]. Moreover, the electronic properties of LDH could be influenced by the surface terminal groups and intrinsic lattice structure of MXene, which in turn significantly affects the catalytic performance of supported catalysts (e.g., Ni2Co-LDHs@AL-Ti3C2 MXene composite, FeNi-LDH/Ti3C2-MXene nanohybrids, and growing Co-BDC MOF with interdiffusion reaction-assisted, etc.) [27–29]. Meanwhile, MXene can be applied to distribute and stabilize flexible LDH, and the Schottky heterostructure with charge redistribution caused by band bending between them can produce an interface that is much more conducive to the activation/adsorption of active materials [30,31]. As a result, the 2D hierarchical LDH@MXene nanohybrids displayed superb OER activity. In addition, LDHs suffer from slightly poor HER activity and lead to a very high water-splitting voltage in alkaline electrolytes. In addition, due to containing vacant d orbitals and unpaired d electrons, the selectivity and activity of the transition metals catalyst can be determined by the surface electronic structure (for example, d-band center and charge), which is an important factor of the catalyst [31]. The P atom possesses a stronger electron-donor ability and larger atomic radius so that it has a more significant influence on the adjustment of the surface charge state [32]. A rational modification with P can affect the electronic state of the metal and form surface defects, thereby optimizing the adsorption energy of the catalyst and improving the catalytic performance [32]. In addition, the surface electron density can be effectively enhanced by P atoms modification and forming various chemical adsorptions to achieve the purpose of molecular activation, thereby further improving the problem of LDH with poor water-splitting activity [33].

Based on the above considerations, a series of Schottky heterostructure electrocatalysts were designed and synthesized by the interface effect between CoFe-LDH and Ti3C2 MXene. Moreover, the water splitting performance was further optimized by modulating the electron density with P dopant. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were also performed to reveal the nature of the manufactured interface. The three-dimensional interconnected macroporous framework should be conducive to the quick obtaining of the electrolyte, and the quick release of gas after the violent electrocatalytic reaction under strong electric density. The independent electrode design (rooting on nickel foam (NF), as a strong current collector) via P-doped Schottky heterostructure interface (P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF) exhibited efficient bifunctional performance toward HER and OER in an alkaline solution. And the excellent stability under the high current density further highlights the great promise of MXene-based nanohybrids in cornerstone energy applications.

The MAX (Ti3AlC2) powders were purchased from Jilin 11 technology Co., Ltd. Lithium fluoride (LiF), hydrochloric acid (HCl), acetone, ethanol, hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), ferric nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O), cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)3·6H2O), urea (CH4N2O), ammonium fluoride (NH4F), sodium hypophosphite (NaH2PO2), and potassium hydroxide (KOH) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemicals were analytical reagent grade and were used as received without further purification.

In order to obtain more rigorous experimental results, firstly, unused NF was successively treated with ultrasound in acetone, concentrated hydrochloric acid (6 M HCl), and ethanol, alternately for several times to remove the oxide films and impurities on the surface. CTAB is a cationic surfactant, which is positively charged in an aqueous solution. Then NF was put into 2 mg/mL CTAB for 3 min to obtain a surface environment surrounded by positive charges. Next, the treated NF was immersed in a 4 mg/mL MXene solution for another 3 min, where MXene is electronegative. So, they could be combined by electrostatic attraction. In order to ensure that MXene can be stably adhered to the surface of NF, the MXene/NF was annealed in a tubular furnace, and then they two would be adsorbed together stably. At this time, the MXene/NF precursor was successfully prepared.

Next, 0.5 mmol Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, 0.5 mmol Co(NO3)3·6H2O, 10 mmol urea, and 4 mmol NH4F were dissolved in 30 mL deionized water under stirring at room temperature to form a yellow solution. Three above solutions were prepared. The solutions were subsequently transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave in which the as-prepared MXene/NF was immersed into the solution, heating at 80 ℃, 100 ℃, and 120 ℃ respectively for 6 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF were collected.

In a typical synthesis process, CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF and 1 g NaH2PO2 were placed on both sides of the ceramic crucible with another crucible covered on the top. Subsequently, the crucibles were heated at 300 ℃ for 1 h under flowing Ar gas at a rate of 5 ℃·min−1. In comparison tests, the control samples with different phosphorus conditions were designed.

The P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF Schottky heterostructure interface was fabricated based on an in situ growth method followed by controllable phosphorization steps ( Fig. 1a). Firstly, selectively etching the Al layer in Ti3AlC2 with LiF/HCl, then performing ultrasonic and centrifugal stripping, Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets with an average lateral size of several hundred nanometers were obtained (Fig. 1b). Then, the positively charged NF treated with the surfactant was wrapped by MXene with an electronegative surface (The experimental methods are shown in Supporting Information). At the same time, the color of NF changed from silver to gray (Fig. S1 and S2, Supporting Information). The network of ultra-thin CoFe-LDH nanosheets was further anchored on MXene/NF frame by a one-step hydrothermal growth method. The panoramic SEM view shows that interconnected CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF are uniformly standing on the MXene/NF frame without recording macropores (Fig. 1c). This structural feature is conducive to exposing more edges and defects and shortening the charge transport path of the electrocatalytic reaction. After sodium hypophosphite (NaH2PO2) treatment, the precursor was further doped with P through the exchanging of heteroatoms. Compared to CoFe-LDH nanosheets, there are no obvious changes in the shape of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, and the vertical arrangement features are well preserved (Fig. 1d). In addition, it can be found that LDH was not oxidized during phosphating (Fig. S3). However the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF has a rougher microscopic surface, and many nanopores are formed at the same time, which will provide additional electroactive centers. The unique characteristic of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF was further identified with the transmission electron microscope (TEM). In Fig. 1e, it reveals the robust coupling of CoFe-LDH nanoplates with MXene owing to its ultra-thin feature of several nanometers. The charge transfer pathway and mass diffusion would be shortened by such an ultrathin 2D nanostructure in electrochemical reactions. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) confirms the generation of CoFe-LDH nanosheets. The two enlarged images in the left of Fig. 1f show the lattice fringes of different crystal faces of the catalyst. The lattice fringes with a space of 0.759 nm, 0.382 nm, and 0.263 nm correspond to the (003), (006), and (012) planes of CoFe-LDH, respectively [34–36]. Besides, the angle between the (006) and the (012) of 80.5° is almost the same as the theoretical value, which further proves the successful growth of LDH (The calculation details are in the Supporting Information). In Fig. 1f, the MXene growth substrate can be seen on the right side of the TEM which means that the ultra-thin nano-layer and LDH are tightly combined. Due to the good adaptability between them, the overall metallicity was effectively improved to enhance the conductivity and ECSA of the catalyst. This unique structure can also be seen more intuitively in Fig. S4 (Supporting Information). Notably, the elemental mapping analysis of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF confirms the homogeneous dispersion of Ti, C, Co, Fe, and P (Fig. 1g). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) characterization results are consistent with this result (Fig. S5, Supporting Information). Among them, all elements were distributed around the NF, and P was distributed in the nano-composites.

The crystal phase structure of samples was characterized through X-ray diffraction (XRD). The XRD patterns of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, CoFe-LDH/NF, and CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF are shown in Fig. 2a. And the etched pattern of MAX is shown in Fig. S6 (Supporting Information), the XRD result in Fig. S6 shows that there is no obvious peak of TiO2, indicating that it was not oxidized during the etching process. For the bare CoFe-LDH/NF, the diffraction peaks at 11.74°, 23.4°, 34.1°, and 35.2° can be assigned to (003), (006), (012), and (009) planes (JCPDS Card No. 50–0235), respectively.[35,36] Strong diffraction peaks near at 45° and 52° can be assigned to the NF in the substrate (Fig. S7 is the XRD of NF. Supporting Information). And for the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, there are no other impurity diffraction peaks after phosphating treatment compared with CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF. The results show that the P atoms were carried out through displacement reaction or interstitial reaction without other impurity phases. As shown in Fig. 2b, the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF shows a special EPR signal with a certain g-value of about 2.001, indicating electrons trapped by surface oxygen vacancies (OVs) [37]. The highest electron spin resonance intensity of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF suggests the presence of massive OVs on the surface, and thus an improved electrocatalytic performance shall be expected [38]. Furthermore, the formation of OVs can be further proved via XPS. The fitted O 1s XPS spectrum of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF has a peak at 531.55 eV after phosphating treatment, which is ascribed to oxygen defect sites with low oxygen coordination [39]. As a result, reaction kinetics, electronic conduction, and electrolyte wettability are improved [40,41]. In order to explore the interface effect between MXene and CoFe-LDH, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) tests were performed on these two materials. The chemical composition and surface electronic states of them were characterized through XPS. The XPS spectra for P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF and the control samples are shown in Fig. 2d–f. In Figs. 2d and 2e, all samples contain two prominent peaks accompanied by two satellite peaks (denoted as Sat.) respectively. Comparably, the peaks of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF and CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF have a slightly positive shift by 0.6 and 0.4 eV towards the higher binding, respectively, which might be influenced by the interaction between flexible CoFe-LDH and stiff MXene [42,43]. Although there are no significant changes of Co 2p for XPS in Fig. 2e, the final test data shows a slight positive shift, which is consistent with Fe 2p. These positive shifts indicate that there is a strong interfacial electronic interaction between CoFe-LDH and MXene, which is essential for rapid charge transfer in this process. In P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF, the peaks at 705–710 eV (Fe 2p) and 775–776 eV (Co 2p) correspond to metal Fe and Co, respectively. The Fe-P bond and Co-P bond are observed in the Fe 2p spectrum at 706–707 eV and Co 2p spectrum at 773 eV, respectively. The P 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 2f) of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF sample further confirms the presence of phosphorus. Not surprisingly, it shows the visible peaks of P 2p, which is assigned to be P-O 133.8 eV (P 2p3/2), 134.9 eV (P 2p1/2). And there is metal-P bond around 130 eV in P 2p spectrum, which corresponds to Fe 2p and Co 2p. Moreover, the physical properties of the catalyst can be confirmed by nitrogen adsorption and desorption test (Fig. S8, Supporting Information). The specific surface area (SSA) of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF and CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF are about 156.01 m2 g−1 and 89.32 m2 g−1, respectively. It shows that the SSA becomes larger after phosphating, demonstrating the largest electrode-electrolyte contact area, which is good for improving the efficiency of the electrocatalytic reaction. And the pore structure of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF is dominated by mesopores. This relatively excellent physical performance could improve the adsorption of electrolyte and improve the efficiency of the catalytic reaction. The above results reveal that the stable P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF composite material was successfully synthesized. In addition, there is a strong interaction between the MXene and CoFe-LDH, and structural stability and electron transfer are promoted by the interface effect. Moreover, the OVs formed by P doping are beneficial to the changing of surface electronic structure of the catalyst and adjusting the energy band position to promote catalytic performance. All in all, the heterostructure materials with heteroatoms doping were synthesized successfully.

Encouraged by the unique microstructure, expected chemical composition, and ideal atomic structure, HER activity of the electrocatalyst was first evaluated by a three-electrode system in 1.0 M KOH. Compared to that of NF, it can be observed that all of the linear sweep voltammogram (LSV) curves shift obviously to the positive direction ( Fig. 3a, Fig. 3b, and Fig. S9). Remarkably, P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF exhibits the lowest overpotential (85 mV) to afford the current density of 10 mA cm−2 among the tested samples, which is comparable to previously reported state-of-the-art Co/Fe-based electrocatalysts (Table S1, Supporting Information). At the same time, the electrocatalytic HER activity of CoFe-LDH with MXene under different reaction time also confirms the superiority of CoFe-LDH-100@MXene/NF (Fig. S10, Supporting Information). And the double-layer capacitance (Cdl) with ECSA further proves this point (Figs S10 and S11, Supporting Information). This provides the basis for the subsequent phosphating reaction. In addition, the overpotential is only 195 mV to reach a high current density of 100 mA cm−2. Moreover, the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF possesses the smallest Tafel slope (98.59 mV dec−1, Fig. 3c) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) (Fig. 3d), revealing the favorable reaction kinetics and the lowest charge transfer resistance, respectively. These results demonstrate that P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF has faster HER kinetics than CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF and CoFe-LDH /NF, confirming the significant influence of P doping and strong interface effect on increasing HER activity. The Cdl associated with ECSA of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF and control samples were investigated by capacitance measurements via cyclic voltammograms under different scan rates (Fig. S12, Supporting Information). As seen from Fig. 3e, P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF possesses the highest Cdl among all the samples, indicating that the Schottky heterostructure electrocatalysts with doped heteroatoms expose a great number of more active sites and it is a feasible way to modulate the morphology. Since the operational stability of the catalyst is a significant criterion in the HER process, the current-time measurement was performed. The P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF exhibites an impressive HER operation stability after 25 h with negligible decay at both current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 3f). Especially, it still maintains the stability of 98.9% in the high current density. And the crystal structure and array morphology of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF electrode after HER cycle test were still maintained well (Figs S13 and S14, Supporting Information). In addition, the electrocatalytic HER activity with different phosphating degrees also confirms the superiority of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF-b (Fig. S15).

The OER catalytic activity of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF and the comparative composites was also evaluated in 1.0 M KOH. The polarization curves with IR-compensation are shown in Fig. 4a. Shockingly, the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF electrode delivers a low overpotential of 246 mV at a current density of 200 mA cm−2, which not only is much smaller than CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF (330 mV), CoFe-LDH/NF (393 mV), MXene/NF (528 mV), and NF (670 mV) but also outperforms most of previously reported Co/Fe-based electrocatalysts (Fig. 4b; Table S2, Supporting Information). The catalytic OER kinetics of the catalyst was further evaluated through the linear fitting Tafel plots obtained from the polarization curves. As shown in Fig. 4c, P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF exhibits the smallest Tafel slope of 53.19 mV dec−1 compared with CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF (81.98 mV dec−1), CoFe-LDH/NF (142.8 mV dec−1), MXene/NF (206.58 mV dec−1), and NF (814.8 mV dec−1), indicating its rapid reaction kinetic within a specific potential range. The EIS was used to reveal the underlying reasons for the prominent OER activity. The smallest resistance of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF means the improved charge-transfer ability with this novel design idea (Fig. 4d). Similar to HER, the electrocatalytic OER activity of CoFe-LDH with MXene under different reaction time confirm the superiority of CoFe-LDH-100 @MXene/NF (Fig. S16, Supporting Information). Besides, the electrocatalytic OER activity with different phosphating degrees also confirms the superiority of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF-b (Fig. S17, Supporting Information). And the OER stability test was also performed at a constant potential of 1.47 V without a significant decrease in current density versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). As shown in Fig. 4e, a negligible decline of current density can be observed under a high voltage during the test, indicating the remarkable stability of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF for OER. Moreover, the crystal structure and array morphology of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF electrode after the OER cycle test were still maintained well (Figs S18 and S19, Supporting Information). To further provide an insight into the origin of the superior OER and HER activity, XPS investigation of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF after the OER and HER cycle test were carried out (Fig. S20, Fig. S21, and Fig. S22, Supporting Information). And there is no offset and attenuation. Meanwhile, the CoFe-OH peaks of the high-resolution O 1s spectrum suggesting the structure of CoFe (oxy)hydroxide on the surface of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF electrode without collapse during the OER process (Fig. 4f and Fig. S23, Supporting Information) [35,44]. Since MXene is easily oxidized, the XPS of Ti and C was explored after the OER cycle reaction (Figs S24 and S25, Supporting Information). The MXene has been slightly oxidized because of Ti-O bond in Ti 2p. However, the main body was successfully retained without severe oxidation. And the XPS result of C 1s proves it because the C-O bond in C 1s is very weak. Based on the above considerations, the formation of a surface hydroxide layer would prevent further oxidation of the catalyst core, and the stable interface between LDH and MXene may be beneficial to improving the adsorption of OH-, thereby increasing the catalytic activity.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Overall water splitting performances and mechanism investigation
ce:section.ce:para: Encouraged by the excellent bifunctional catalytic activates for HER and OER, the overall water splitting performance was assessed under a two-electrode system by utilizing P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF as working electrode at both the anode and the cathode in an alkaline electrolyzer. As shown by the LSV polarization curves for overall water splitting in Fig. 5a, P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF//P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF achieves a cell voltage of only 1.52 V at 10 mA cm−2, whereas 1.67 V requires for commercial Pt/C@NF//IrO2 @NF. Notably, the overall water splitting performance of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF catalyst also surpassed those of recently reported transition metal-based catalysts (Table S3, Supporting Information). The long-term durability was also recorded during long-term continuous operation. Encouragingly, the current density kept basically a constant during the cycling of 100 h at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 5b). Taking into account the practical application of the electrocatalysts, the chronoamperometry measurement of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF under a larger current density (100 mA cm−2) for overall water splitting was also carried out. The fluctuation of current density for P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF could almost be negligible under durability experiments up to 100 h, suggesting excellent stability of the catalysts. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed the mechanism between the introduced MXene and CoFe-LDH and explained the insight of phosphating in depth. The density of states (DOS) of the CoFe-LDH, MXene, and CoFe-LDH@MXene composite were calculated in accordance with density functional theory to investigate the electronic structures (Fig. 5c). The corresponding DFT calculations reveal that the MXene and CoFe-LDH are metallic and semiconductive, respectively. The Schottky heterostructure of the CoFe-LDH@MXene indicates the intrinsic metallic properties. Notably, the DOS of the original MXene near the Fermi energy level is weaker than those CoFe-LDH@MXene heterostructures (Fig. 5c), implying that the electron conductivity could be further enhanced by the interface effect of them, which is consistent with the EIS test results. It can be proved by the conductivity tests (Fig. S26). This is attributable to the fact that it produced an electron-rich region on MXene and a hole-rich region on CoFe-LDH, resulting in the movement of the Fermi level. In addition, the electron transfer among the interfaces made Co and Fe atoms more positively charged than pure CoFe-LDH nanosheets, which is consistent with the previous XPS results in Fig. 2. Next, the differences in the DOS of CoFe-LDH@MXene and P-CoFe-LDH@MXene materials are shown in Fig. 5d. Especially, the DOS intensity of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene increases significantly near the Fermi energy level. After the oxygen atoms are partially replaced by P atoms of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene in Fig. 5e, the surface electron density around the P atoms increase significantly after the P doping treatment, indicating that the electronegativity of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene can be enhanced by the charge carrier aggregation and the conductivity will be further improved (The atomic structure diagram of the P-CoFe-LDH@MXene in the upper diagram of Fig. 5e and Fig. S27. The charge difference distribution of the side view and top view of P-CoFe-LDH@MXene are in Fig. S28 and the bottom diagram of Fig. 5e, respectively.). Due to the higher electronegativity and longer bond length of Co/Fe-O-P bonds than those of Co/Fe-O bonds, the attraction for the 3d electrons of Co+/Co2+/Co3+ or Fe+/Fe2+/Fe3+ in P-CoFe-LDH@MXene is weakened, and the energy of electron transport in the redox reaction is decreased, resulting in the faster reaction kinetics [45]. These results again identify that the electron transport ability, surface electron density, and the redox reactions of heterostructures were enhanced by the unique character. In fact, the Schottky barrier obviously leads to redistribution of electrons and band bending around the interface, which allows electrons to be transferred spontaneously from MXene to CoFe-LDH until the work function equilibrium (Fig. 5f). The electrons redistribution on the Schottky heterointerface can not only establish a continuous electron transmission path between the semiconductor and metal phases, increase high-density active sites, but also reduce the energy barrier of reaction intermediates effectively, and accelerate the overall splitting water rate. The ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy analysis and energy band diagram before Schottky contact are shown in Fig. S29. Meanwhile, the surface-active sites can be significantly improved after phosphating treatment. In addition, the comparison of the d-band centers is shown in Fig. S30, it has been considered as a good descriptor of reaction kinetics [46,47]. The up-shift of the d-band center indicates a distinctive anti-bonding state. Therefore, stronger bond occurs with the d-band center shifts. As we all know, the active center of transition metal needs to be optimized the adsorption stability of the intermediate to improve the superior performance of water splitting [33,48]. When the P atom was introduced into the CoFe-LDH@MXene (P-CoFe-LDH@MXene), the d-band center of the CoFe-LDH@MXene continues to be positively shifted, as shown in Fig. S30, indicating that the reaction kinetics of the Schottky heterointerface catalyst can be further optimized to promote the overall splitting water ability. This explains why the catalyst has such an excellent overall water splitting ability. As demonstrated by the above results, the doping of surface heteroatoms not only induces electron transport within the heterojunction but also allows the modulation of surface electron density for promoting the intrinsical catalytic activity toward overall water splitting. Herein, constructing a Schottky heterojunction with superior electrocatalytic abilities paves a way for exploring other exceptional bifunctional overall splitting water electrocatalysts.

In summary, Schottky heterostructure catalyst was fabricated through ingeniously integrating the metallic MXene with semiconductor CoFe-LDH. The formed heterojunction with self-driven charge transfer interfaces promoted the metallicity and electron redistribution of the catalyst. In addition, the surface electron density and the metallicity of the Schottky heterojunction can be further optimized by the doping of P atoms. Experiments and DFT calculations proved that MXene and CoFe-LDH have a strong interface effect, and the P dopant not only modifies the surface electron density effectively but also provides massive vacancies, resulting in a high electrochemically active site and optimized reaction kinetics. The as-synthesized P-CoFe-LDH@MXene/NF exhibited remarkable stability and excellent bifunctional activity in alkaline solution. The unique catalyst was prepared on the NF self-supporting electrode, and the design concept is easily amplified, we expect that it can be used for practical water splitting, and even for other electrocatalytic reactions such as nitrogen reduction reaction and oxygen reduction reaction. We believe that this work provides insights into the field of energy storage and conversion.

Lequan Deng: Methodology, Investigation, Visualization, Data curation, Writing – original draft, Preparation. Kang Zhang: Writing – original draft, Methodology, Data curation. Dong Shi: Data curation, preparation. Shengfu Liu: Investigation, Validation. Deqin Xu: Methodology, Data curation. Yongliang Shao: Writing – review & editing, Supervision. Jianxing Shen: Conceptualization, Supervision. Yongzhong Wu: Validation, Project administration. Xiaopeng Hao: Writing – review & editing, Supervision.
